CHINA AIRWAYS FEDERAL INC. U. S. A.
3 CANTON ROAD
SHANGHAI
NORTH AMERICAN AVIATION, INC.
INTERCONTINENT AVIATION, INC.
CURTISS-WRIGHT CORPORATION
CURTISS AEROPLANE AND MOTOR COMPANY
WRIGHT AERONAUTICAL CORPORATION
CURTISS. WRIGHT AIRPLANE COMPANY
DOUGLAS AIRCRAFT COMPANY
SPERRY GYROSCOPE COMPANY
HANKOW, Saturday, June 3, 1933.
Dear
Family:
We arrived here yesterday afternoon at
5 P.M.
after a
beautiful and most
interesting trip down
from Chungking through the gorges.
We flew low in a regular
Loening with landing wheels removed - in other words a flying
boat.
The pilot who has been flying this 500-mile-route for
nearly two years
is a great character.
He is from Nashville
and knows the Holdneress and others
from there.
He is very
good looking - a big fellow about 5:11 and weighs 180 or
thereabouts
- his drawl is not very pronounced but you would
know he hails from the South.
His name is Charles
S.
Vaughn
but he is known
on every steamboat, gunboat,
ci ty
and
town -
by all nationalities including Chinese as
"Chilly".
All up
and down
the upper Yangtze for the 500 miles the expression
"Here comes
Chilly" is a part of the every day language and
among the Chinese
"Here comes Chilly" means aviation or air
mail.
He has a flat in Hankow where lots of passenger and
all
the pilots make their headquarters.
He charges the
pilots
on
the lower river run $6.00 Mex. per day and they
sign "chits" for drinks or extras. (Any memo, short note
or
club slip over here is a "chit")
He has a good Chinese boy
as cook and another as
servant - press suits, shine shoes, etc.
When Chilly goes along
the river all the boats whistle a
salute
and Chilly flashes the most engaging smile you've ever
seen and waves to crew and passengers as he roars by.
He has
a stop at Ichang where
the gorges begin and there is
stationed
the American "flag-pan"
as the naval officers call the flag
the Yangtsze River flat bottomed gun boats.
sanded on at on near t bottle an boo a am ral
called out "come on over Chilly" so we got in a sampan and
jointed the officers on the Luzon,
which is the "flag-pans"
official name,
and had a cup of
coffee and a sandwich while
Chilly's Chinese co-pilot Hugh Chen was supervising the
refueling of the ship.
I noticed as we approached the flag
ship that all
the sailors and even the cook said "Hello Chilly".
If he gets stuck at Ichang, Chilly boards the Luzon with any
foreign passengers he may have and spends the night on board
flying on
the
next morning to
Chungking.
In two years he has
never had an accident of any kind and he is so well known
that his plane is filled to capacity on almost every trip.
He
writes notes to the foreign passengers and Chen writes notes
to the Chinese
passengers pointing out interesting places, etc.
At Chungking
Chilly had a flat but every time he arrived there
different people insisted on entertaining him and so he gave
up his flat and for two years has stayed with friends up there.

.?.
Well so much for Chilly - you may meet him
because he is going home leave in August and maybe to get
married although he cleims his girl 1s still saying "no"
insteed of tyag",
He has been over here 3 years and all
pilots set 3 months home with expenses end Full
pay every
vearise
He savs he wants to be back here by mas.
Well to return to our flight. We left Chungking
94 9 05
and flew Bast through beautiful country very much
like Lake George except the broad Yangtze 1g coffee color
rather toad one.
China is much more enjoyable from the air
than from the surface because you see only the beautiful
green country and you miss all the squallor, dirt and most
unpleasant of
the
all,
the odors.
Someone was asked
Chinese National Anthem.
he
ragne ever heard the
He replied that at no place
National air but that he could smell it
almost anywhere.
Our first landing was at Wahnsien which 1s
quaint olty aw the upper end of une gorges.
From there we
flew close to the river through the gorges which rise steep
on either side from 500 to 1500 feet.
There we flew for a
hundred miles about 30 feet off the water. (It is now Sunday
morning and again I am flying dow the Yangtze with Shanghai
as our last stop,
We have just left Chekiang where the ship
which we were supposed to take back to Shanghai yesterday
morning was forced down Friday afternoon by motor trouble.
The
pilot Howard Norris and mechanic "Swede" Larsen met us at the
float - the engine is in bad shape and the plane will have to
be loaded on to a river boat and shipped back to Shanghai.
The
pilot and mochanio will stay with the ahip until.
asked Norris
to ouv me
some Chekiang chine
it is loaded.
which is quite
ramous and think very beautiful. - it is called "thousand
flowers" and I wrote to you about it once before.. The ILOwers
are all different colors against a blueish gold back ground or
black back ground.
I ordered the lighter back ground and
will send one of the plates to you for your approval or
disapprovel.
the latter, I can easily dispose of them in
Shanghei at more than Norris will pay for them.
He thought he
could get a fairly good set of six pieces each for $60.00 Mex.
or lb.00 our money.
To go
on with my story
the gorges
we passed many picturesque junks with their delapidated sails,
miscelaneous cargos struggling up stream against the swift
current and white capped rapids of the muddy snarling Yangtze.
A rope 1s attached to the mast of the junk - a long long bamboo
twisted rope - trackers frequently stark naked strain with all
their strength, their bere feet gripping the tow path worn
smoothe by generations of their sweating chanting grunting
ancestors who
the
for thousands of years have fought up stream along
same path towing the
type or cargo in the same Kind
of junks.
The latter very in desion so that experienced
OUSeMYOLIS con rela glance where the junk is from.
боне
of them will travel from Shanghai to the borders of Tibet.
At
places along the cliffs the tracker path is hew out of solid
rock and the trackers, from six to ten men depending on the
size of the tow, cling to the narrow path with rock above their
heads - one shoulder rubbing the cliff and the other above
yawing chasm 100 feet above the river where a slip means just

one more Chinese
ancestor
"Chillyt
• comes down lover still
passes close to a river steam boat which appears to be
standing stIll but 18 actually running with every norse in 18
horsepower pulling his darndest against the swift current.
Oren
and passengers wave as we flash by - ust caught a glimpse of
the flag, it was British.
he take the bends of the river wth
gentle banking
turn • the air is smoote • a shoud be
TO = OUT
Chinese companions - a man and his wife are
both asleep, apparently old customers of Chilly's.
Along the
steer sides
OT the gorges wherever any soil is eveilable
terraced rice fields get a rest while the farmer coolies watch
us pass - they never change expressions or wave.
Little shrines
are carved out of the rock at many places and ocassionally you
see a small pagoda.
the break bulk
Emerging from the gorges we land at Ichang -
station and transhipment point between the
and lower vangusze.
Ichang
isko tor canes which are
upper
carved
I had radioed our agent to have some there
for me to look at and bought three for $1.00 Mex. each. (We have
Just landed to deliver and take on mall at Anking
- our station
there is a raft like pontoon and attached to it is half a junk
in which is a weiting room.
me staved tiered rew mutes and
then take off for Nanking.
The fly over the ancient city of
Anking.
It is entirely surrounded by a high wall with a moat.
one gate - 1s the only entrance on the river side and one or
the land side. We have one Chinese passenger who wakes up only
to get out at each station and take a smoke.
He has on a long
blue gown and a skull cap like Guido Pantaleoni wears)
arrived at Hankow Friday afternoon - it was quite hot 88°
in
the shade and my winter suit was uncomfortable.
Chilly's boy
pressed it for me which at least made it look more presentable.
We had dinner at Chilly's and then went to a movie
and Tomorrow".
"Tomorrow
I had seen it before but didn't say so because
they all wanted to go and it was the only movie in town.
Satur-
day A.M. we saw Chilly off for Chungking again and went shopping.
I bought some
"shortg" with stockings to match - olive drab
and felt much more comfortable - also felt (but wasn't) more
conspicuous
We had lunch at Chilly's place and as it was
raining:
just
writing,
sat around until the plene, in which
I
антонот
came in at 3 o'clock.
Then we went out to the clut
and had e swim after which we drank tea on the porch
• watched
a cricket game
'Just fwanoy" and listened to a band,
or render
orchestra , play some very good music which wound up with
"God
Save the King"
the king'.
amid much bumping or glasses and toasts = 1t was
s birthday quite en
seem
event it seems among the English
to control the Hankow cub
well as every other
cLub an chine except the American and rench luds at Shanghai.
The cricket game was the first I have ever seen and I found
it much less boring than I expected - probably because one
American was playing and refused to .
make futile passes at the
ball but instead took a full man-sized baseball swing and
knocked the ball
the ball
out of the lot every time the "bowler" threw
toward his wicket.
After the American had scored
45 runs the game was stopped for some reason - probably for tea
or perhaps they despaired of
Over
getting him out.
However all
the Britishers gave him a great hand and didn't seem to resent

his breaking up the game
un-American in the sense

of the all too customery swash

for the immediate section around

allegiance to

receive anything from,

the National Treasury at Nanking so
guess its about the same as the U.S. in the last analysis -
except the people of China do not have to put up with a senate
and Congress and you must admit that is one blessing which goes
far to make up for many hardships.
Over here a man in public
life can eat Swifts bacon without any danger of impeachment for
Severing bag bus ness.
Ten resc o the actions or me Unsa
senate can not help but admire the Chinese system.
least a leader of men must be a real man among his fellows - he
must possess a keen quick mind and a two fisted virility.
Oh
well anyhow Nanking.
Leaving Wanking we have another passenger
who we learn frog the station manager 1s Mr. Chen, Police
Commissioner of Hankow, formerly Police Commissioner
I'm told he lost his .
at Shanghai.
Job at Shanghai because he caught the
Mayor smuggling opium at which job it seems the Mayor had been
working for several years quite to the advantage of said Mayor's
bank account.
Mr. leyor was given someother job and the Police
Commissioner was told to be less zealous.
I guess they were
afrald he might get "too high up on the hog" as brother Bill says.
